==Japanese==

===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
{{wikipedia|Fruit}}
[[File:Culinary_fruits_front_view.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|果物}} (''kudamono'', ''kabutsu''): various kinds of '''{{l|en|fruit}}'''.]]
</div>
{{ja-kanjitab|く|もの|yomi=kun}}
Literally “tree's thing”. Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=くだもの|木|tr1=ku|t1=tree|pos1=shift from ancient ''ko'' pronunciation|だ|tr2=da|pos2=possessive marker between two nouns, only found in a few compounds|物|tr3=mono|t3=thing}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

The medial ''da'' is also seen in {{m|ja|獣|tr=kedamono||beast|lit=hairy thing}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|くだもの|acc=2|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|くだもの}}

# edible [[fruit]] that grows on trees or shrubs, such as [[orange]]s and [[apple]]s, or [[sweet]] edible fruit that grows along the ground, such as [[strawberry|strawberries]] and [[melon]]s

=====Synonyms=====
* {{ja-r|フルーツ}}

=====Derived terms=====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|果物急ぎ|くだもの いそぎ}}: the act of often taking something from a selection of fruit or other sweets put out at a social gathering; a person who is quick to take items from such a selection
* {{ja-r|果物屋|くだものや}}: a [[fruit]] [[store]]
* {{ja-r|果物籠|くだもの かご}}: a [[fruit basket]]
{{der-bottom}}

=====See also=====
* {{ja-r|果実|かじつ}}: fruit (edible or otherwise)
* {{ja-r|実|み}}: a [[seed]], a [[berry]], a [[fruit]], a [[nut]]
* {{ja-r|青果物|せいかぶつ}}: [[garden]] stuff, [[greenstuff]]
* {{ja-r|八百屋|やおや}}: a [[greengrocer]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|か|ぶつ|yomi=on}}
{{IPAchar|/kwabut͡su/}} → {{IPAchar|/kabut͡su/}}

Possibly from {{der|ja|ltc|sort=かぶつ|-}} compound {{m|ltc|果物|tr=*guɑ *miət|lit=fruit thing}}. Compare modern {{cog|cmn|果物}} reading ''guǒwù'' {{qualifier|rare}}, {{cog|yue|-}} ''gwo<sup>2</sup> mat<sup>6</sup>'' {{qualifier|rare}}.

Rarely used in modern {{cog|ja|-}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=kanon|かぶつ}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かぶつ|hhira=くわぶつ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=かぶつ|rare}} [[fruit]]

=====Usage notes=====
The ''kudamono'' reading is much more common in modern Japanese.
